facts.text: Appellant is a private limited company formed under the Companies Act of 1956 to take over assets and liabilities of predecessor company.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a private limited companypany, formed under the Companies Act of 1956, to take over the assets and liabilities of another companypany as also its outstanding companytracts.

facts.text: Predecessor company obtained lease of considerable area of forest land in North Andaman for exploiting timber.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that some time ago the predecessor companypany obtained a lease of a companysiderable area of forest land in the North Andaman with a view to exploiting its timber.

facts.text: Predecessor company chartered vessel Eastern Venture owned by Newland Steamship Co. Ltd. of Hongkong by charter-party executed in London on August 25, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: One such vessel was Eastern Venture, owned by Newland Steamship Co. Ltd. of Hongkong, which the predecessor companypany hired by a charter-party executed in London on August 25,1954.

facts.text: Charter-party was uniform time charter for six months with option of another three months, renewed or extended thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: The period companyered by it was six months, with an option of another three months for the charter, but it appears that since the expire of the original term, the charter-party has been renewed or its terms extended from time to time.

facts.text: Vessel changed hands at least twice after original charter.

anchor.surface_text: Although the vessel appears to have changed hands at least twice and the period of the origins charter-party also expired, as I have just started, long ago,

facts.text: Terms of charter-party dated August 25, 1954 continued in force with slight modification.

anchor.surface_text: it is number disputed that terms and companyditions of the deed of the August 25,1954, have companytained to be in force with one slight modification to which I shall presently refer.

facts.text: Clause 6: Charterers to pay hire 16s. per ton on 5,250 tons every 30 days in advance in cash in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 6 of the charter-party provided that the charterers were to pay as hire I6s. per ton on the vessels dead weight of 5,250 tons per 30 This payment of hire was to be made without discount every 30 days in advance and, according to clause 6, it was to be made in cash in Calcutta.

facts.text: Clause 26: Hire per clause 6 to be paid by telegraphic transfer to London; addendum for cash in London or Hongkong.

anchor.surface_text: Somewhat inconsistently, the charter-party came to companytain another provision in clause 26 which said that the hire in accordance with clause 6 was to be paid by telegraphic transfer to London. By an addendum inserted and it was agreed that payment would be made in cash in London or Hongkong.

facts.text: Clause 14: Charterers or agents to advance to Master necessary funds for ordinary disbursements, charging 6% interest p.a., deducted from hire.

anchor.surface_text: Clause I4 read as follows The charterers or their agents to advance to the Master, if required, necessary funds for ordinary disbursements for the vessel,s account at any port, charging only interest at 6 per cent., p.a., such advances to be deducted form hire.

facts.text: Vessel employed mainly between Calcutta and North Andaman.

anchor.surface_text: In the main, it appears to have plied between Calcutta and the North Andaman.

facts.text: Clegg, Cruickshank & Co. Ltd., Calcutta, local agents of owners, and appellant undertook to pay income-tax on owners' freight earnings.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Clegg, Cruickshank and Co. Ltd., who were the local agents of the owners, and thereafter the appellant companypany itself, undertook to the Income-tax authorities to pay any income-tax for which the owners, might be liable on their freight earnings.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued clearance certificates till February 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently on the faith of that guarantee, the Income-tax Officer went of issuing clearance certificate during the initial period without any question and that state of things went on till February 1956.

facts.text: ITO letter dated February 21, 1956 inquired if hire paid per clause 6 and amount paid/payable to non-resident owners.

anchor.surface_text: In February 1956, the Income-tax Officer, then dealing with the matter, became a little more inquisitive and following some discussion with the representatives of the appellant companypany, he required them by a letter, dated February 21,1956,

facts.text: Company replied on March 6, 1956 that hire paid per clause 26, not clause 6, annexed statement of disbursements Rs.52,109-11-0 (Sep 1954-Mar 1955) and Rs.69,768-13-6 (Apr 1955-Feb 1956).

anchor.surface_text: The companypany replied to the Income-tax Officer, s letter on March 6, 1956, and informed him that the hire had been paid as per clause 26 of the charter-party, irrespective of clause 6. ... The figures entered in the third companyumn showed the between September 1954 and March 1955 the total amount of the disbursements had been Rs. 52,109-11-0 and similarly between April 1955 and February 1956 the total amount of the disbursements had been Rs. 69,768-13-6.

facts.text: Disbursements consisted of advances to master, costs of repairs, commission to local agents.

anchor.surface_text: The disbursements companysisted of advances made to the master, companyts of repairs and companymission paid to the local agents of the owners.

facts.text: ITO on March 17, 1956 demanded tax u/s 18(3B) on Rs.52,109 and Rs.69,768 as constructively received by non-resident owner.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, on March 17,1956, he addressed a letter to the appellate companypany in the following terms ... It is aparent from the enclosures to the said letter that Rs. 52,109 and Rs. 69,768 were companystructively received in India by the number-resident owner of the above mentioned vessel during 1954-55 and 1955-56 respectively.

facts.text: Vessel changed hands to Pan Norse Steamship Co. S.A. of Panama, then to Wallem & Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the vessel had changed hands a second time, passing first from the ownership of the Newland Steamship Co. Ltd. to that of Pan Norse Steamship Co. S.A. of Panama, and Next to the ownership of Messrs. Wallem Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Appellant paid tax demanded by challans on May 18, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In the end, the appellant companypany paid the tax demanded by three chilliness on May 18,1956.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition under Art 226 on May 18, 1956; rule issued, discharged by Sinha J.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on May 18,1956, the appellant moved this companyrt under article 226 of the Constitutions for a rule on the Income-tax Officer, directing him to show cause why a writ in the nature of certiorari should number be issued, ... A rule was issued on that application, but at the final hearing it was discharged by Sinha, J.

facts.text: Present appeal against order discharging the rule by Sinha J.

anchor.surface_text: It is against the order discharging the rule that the present appeal is directed.

facts.text: Petitioner's contention: Disbursements under clause 14 were loans, not part payments of hire.

anchor.surface_text: The amounts paid on account of disbursements had been paid under the provisions of clause 14 of the charter-party and having been so paid, they companystituted loans advanced to the owners and number part payments of the hire.

facts.text: Court finding: Advances under clause 14 were pre-payments of hire, not loans; constructively received by owners in India.

anchor.surface_text: the advances made in the present case were number loan, but pre-payments, of portions of the hire that even assuming that they were loans, that character borne by them initially is immaterial ... it was to my mind, companystructively received by the owners in Calcutta

facts.text: Disbursements included Rs.32,092-5-9 to Clegg Cruickshank, Rs.9,028 for repairs and bunker.

anchor.surface_text: the petition with which the appellant came to the companyrt itself stated in paragraph 21 that of the sums paid out on account of disbursements on which the Income-tax Offer had levied tax, Rs. 32,092-5-9 had been paid to Clegg, Cruickshank and Co. Ltd., and Rs 9,028 had been paid to over repairs to the vessel

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner on June 7, 1956, pending.

anchor.surface_text: Yet it number transpires that it actually preferred an appeal against the very order which it was challenging by the petition on June 7, 1956.

holdings.text: Advances stipulated for in clause 14 of the charter-party were not loans but pre-payments of a part of the hire.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the authorities to which I have just referred and the principles to which I have adverted it appears to me that advances stipulated for in clause 14 of the charter-party in the present case were not loans, but were pre-payments of a part of the hire, for which the charter agreed to allow a certain amount of rebate in the form of interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of clause 14 allowing deduction from hire and interest as rebate; follows authorities like Allison v. Bristol distinguishing loans from prepayments based on charter terms.

holdings.text: Even assuming advances were initially loans, they were repaid in India by deduction from hire due to owners, constituting constructive receipt in India by non-resident owners.

anchor.surface_text: Even assuming that the advances when made were loans... it was to my mind, constructively received by the owners in Calcutta, as rightly held by the Income-tax Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deduction from hire applies owners' money to repay advances; cannot repay with own money; cites Keshav Mills on application of money per instructions.

holdings.text: Payments made on account of disbursements were amounts chargeable under the provisions of the Income-tax Act within section 18(3B).

anchor.surface_text: The only question is whether the payments with which this case is concerned, namely, the payments made on account of disbursements, were amounts chargeable to Indian income-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Chargeable' means liable to computation under heads in s.6 as gross receipts; s.18(3C) contemplates proportionate; follows Supreme Court in Aggarwal Chamber and English cases.

holdings.text: Even if advances were part-payments of hire, they were chargeable under s.18(3B) as sums liable under heads of income, not requiring net taxable determination.

anchor.surface_text: they were yet not chargeable under the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act and, therefore, not within the ambit of section 18(3B). I am of opinion that this contention also cannot succeed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payer deducts on gross sums; final adjustments at assessment; Supreme Court in Aggarwal confirms deductions not concerned with ultimate taxability.

holdings.text: Payments for ordinary disbursements not exempt from being chargeable as income merely because earmarked for expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: the payments in the present case had been made for ordinary disbursements on the vessels account and, therefore, the amounts concerned were clearly earmarked for expenditure. ... This contention is also plainly not tenable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of receipt determined on receipt, not subsequent application; follows Epping Forest case rejecting earmarking argument.

holdings.text: Writ of certiorari can correct errors of law apparent on the face of the record even if made within jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: the writ of certiorari had at one time fallen into desuetude ... errors of law are considered to be amenable to correction by the writ, if such errors appear on the face of the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Updates scope per Northumberland and Nat Bell; supervision includes observance of law in exercise of jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Income-tax Officer's letter dated March 17, 1956 is a speaking order as it states reasons including constructive receipt.

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax Officers letter of March 17, 1956, which contains his order, clearly speaks. ... the whole basis ... is that the amounts ... had been constructively received by the non-resident in India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter gives reasons for liability under s.18(3B)/(7); not mute order.

holdings.text: Writ under Art.226 denied due to appellant's lack of candor in concealing pendency of parallel statutory appeal.

anchor.surface_text: although the appellant had actually filed an appeal ... it was insisting even on September 3, 1956 ... that it had no adequate or legal remedy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative remedy not absolute bar but discretion considers conduct; follows Rashid on parallel remedies and lack of propriety; appellant disingenuous.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the authorities to which I have just referred and the principles to which I have adverted it appears to me that advances stipulated for in clause 14 of the charter-party in the present case were not loans, but were pre-payments of a part of the hire, for which the charter agreed to allow a certain amount of rebate in the form of interest.
